awd_titl_txt: CPS: Small: Collaborative Research: CYDER: CYbersecure Distribution systems with power Electronically interfaced Renewables
awd_abstract_narration:
The research goal of this project is to design a comprehensive methodology for cybersecurity monitoring and mitigation of the electric power distribution system with a multitude of dynamical devices that are prone to cyberattacks as well as power electronically interfaced renewable generation units. The power electronics interfaces complicate the control and operation of the distribution system because of their sensitivity to undesired disturbances. By promoting a more secure power system, this work helps increase the resiliency of the distribution system to extreme events, which is in line with the U.S. national priorities. Moreover, this work promotes teaching and learning by (i) educating and training graduate students through several programs including a week-long practicum hosted at an industry site; (ii) disseminating the results of our work via conference presentations and publications; and (iii) introducing significant updates in the syllabi of two courses. This work also increases participation of underrepresented minorities via active recruitment. 

The overarching research goal of this project is to design a comprehensive methodology for cybersecurity monitoring and mitigation in systems with a multitude of dynamical devices that are prone to cyberattacks. To demonstrate the performance of our proposed algorithms, we study their application for an electric power distribution system as a critical cyberinfrastructure, which includes substations, feeder devices, and smart meters. The electric power grid's growing dependency on information and communication technology (ICT) significantly increases its vulnerability to cyber attacks. A major area of concern is the security of supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) systems that the power grids rely upon for monitoring and control functions. To address these challenges, our specific objectives are (i) detection of cyberthreats on the distribution system, (ii) mitigation of and response to cyberintrusions especially with power electronically interfaced renewables via multiagent-based algorithms as well as trajectory shaping and frequency regulation strategies, and (iii) preparing the next generation of cyber-aware engineers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project, altogether, are a holistic approach toward detection and mitigation of cyberattacks on the electric power grid. There were three main novel outcomes:

(i)                 A learning-based decentralized mechanism for attack target prediction in real time: Cyberattacks launched against the distribution systems tend to target multiple nodes and substations. Therefore, predicting the future targets of an ongoing attack with some certainty is useful for proactive and reactive mitigation. A metric quantifies the certainty of the prediction. While the literature acknowledges the need for such mitigation, the centralized methods can be prone to single point failures and do not account for other factors, apart from load size, which also influences the decisions of the attacker. Thus, the decentralized mechanism proposed in this project, which is enhanced with machine learning capabilities to progressively fine-tune predictions is a paradigm shift from the state-of-the-art. It accounts for other factors such as existing cyber vulnerabilities at the target node, and how critical load served by the node is. It therefore is more reliable and accurate.

(ii)              Optimized physical and communication level mitigation: Following predictions, immediate communication level mitigation is enforced. This entails the optimal tightening of security measures (such as number of login attempts allowed, etc.) in such a manner as to be commensurate with the level of threat perceived, as measured by the certainty of prediction. If and when a user-defined number of nodes alert of potential attack, the distribution grid is optimally reconfigured to minimize the impact of attacks on the physical grid. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first instance of both communication level and physical grid level mitigation performed with attack target predictions. The strategy is also both reactive and proactive. Mitigation techniques found in existing literature focus on one or the other type of mitigation, and tends to be only reactive.

(iii)            Cyber asset recovery: In cases where the attack is widespread and the attacker gains control over cyber assets (such as routers, etc.), remote control of the power grid may be difficult. The existing literature, although acknowledging the need for cyber asset recovery, primarily deals with the restoration of the physical power grids. In this project, a systematic algorithm for cyber system recovery and its integration with power system restoration is proposed. This project addresses the issue of practical communication channel and asset recovery in the face of constraints on the communication channel when widespread attacks are conducted.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2022
Modified by: Chen-Ching Liu
